At 16:29 14/11/2005, you wrote:
>Ian, can you explain further #2?  What do you mean by "leaves some
>conventions unspecified?"  As long as you know the node(s) being
>connected and keep track of them as NEAT normally does anyway, why
>is this issue specific to recurrent connections?  Or maybe I just
>don't know what's meant by an "unspecified convention?"  I think
>maybe what you're saying is that what is considered recurrent in
>some individuals may not deserve that designation in others, but I'm
>not certain.

This is where we have a situation like:

A -> B -> C ->D
A-> B' ->C' ->D

If individual-1 connects C to B'  and individual-2 connects C' to B, 
that what has happened is that the ancestor was ambiguous on this 
point (of the relative order of some pairs of nodes) and the 
individuals 1 and 2 have established conventions for those orders, 
but not in a manner that is compatible with one-another....

The other class of approach defines all these orders from the start, 
but therefor cannot do one of those two connections, even though they 
are non-recurrent.

Does that make sense?

         Ian



In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
